The black community in America like many others has a culture comprised of strong in group preference Despite things like the disproportionately high rate of black on black crime there still exists a near universal mutual respect shared by black people for being black even if it s not expressed explicitly Because of that racial betrayal is one of the most emotionally charged offenses within the black community And titles for this offense range from Uncle Tom Sambo House Nigga and most commonly Coon I know a lot of right wing conservative leaning blacks will argue that Coon is just a term used to silence blacks for wrong think Others will probably argue that it s just another cancerous form of identity politics And sometimes that is true but not always And while some people black and non black alike may not recognize the concept of coon to be legitimate in the black community it is an established cultural axiom In this video I wanted to take a shot at explaining from the perspective of a black person what exactly makes someone guilty of being a coon Let s get started First let s define our terms Now there s a lot of different definitions for the word coon According to Urban Dictionary a coon is a black actor or actress who takes roles that stereotypically portrays black people which I m not sure is accurate because I find examples like character James Carter from Rush Hour who is the stereotypical black American sidekick to be fucking hilarious Or the boys of Summer from The Wire who play the role of stereotypical young black American men selling drugs I love all these characters and to my knowledge they re all equally beloved by a majority of black demographics too so I m not sure if it s only cooning when it s a stereotype that black people don t like or you know whatever Another definition according to Webster is an insulting or contemptuous term for a black person Again while vaguely true these definitions aren t really what I m talking about So since I couldn t find a definition that matches the context of which I ll be referring to the term throughout this video I went ahead and wrote my own In my opinion I think a sufficient definition of the word coon as it s most commonly used by black people would be this A black person displaying favoritism to non black people usually white whilst collectively condemning their own race for not being more culturally identical to the race they favor The reason I chose this definition is because the nature of cooning isn t how many describe it It s not merely acting white nor is it merely black on black criticism Rather cooning is a sociological action one that requires a conscious intent to subvert or defame black identity We ll get into some examples of what I would say are reasonable perceived cases of cooning in just a bit but first let s talk about what cooning is not Oftentimes people misattribute cooning to mean anything another black person does that they themselves don t like And when people unreasonably use language it makes the meaning of the term pretty useless And the term coon has been hella abused in this respect For example a black person having a romantic relationship with someone of another race is not inherently cooning Is it possible that they re doing so because they have insecurities about their own race culture etc and want to distance themselves from their blackness Sure It s also possible that they have no issue with being black and the person accusing them of cooning are themselves insecure and are projecting their emotions onto an innocent relationship It s much more likely that you re just salty and bitter because they didn t choose you but I ain t trying to hurt nobody s feelings Another example of unreasonable use of the word coon is the classic you talk white If you re so stupid as to think that the adoption of proper English means that someone is pandering to whites bruh Being literate is not in opposition to black people or black culture Other examples include claims that you know wearing your jeans weighs high makes you a coon straightening or coloring your hair makes you a coon not voting for Obama or Democrats makes you a coon I could go on and on with how stupid some of this shit can be And I ve learned from experience that trying to reason with stupid people is more than often a waste of time so we re gonna leave it at that While these are some of the dumbest examples of coon accusations they still fall under the definition outlined earlier that being a perception of disloyalty to the black collective Now let s talk about some other examples of cooning which even I as a pretty solid individualist can understand being classified as such Cooning from my experience seems to manifest itself in one of two forms those being passive and aggressive Passive cooning is probably the most common A good example of this phenomena would be CNN host Don Lemon Now Don is someone who I ll criticize for a number of things His mainstream leftist propaganda his incessant whining about racism or his hilariously mediocre career as a journalist I m a dog swimmer Thank you Mike Tyson I love you I love you too But none of those things make him a coon Instead Don Lemon s cooning stems from his appeals to improve the black community by whitewashing the culture You see Don Lemon is as mainstream as mainstream blacks come He s made a career out of assimilating into the milieu of white elites And he s fared quite well as a result Not only Lemon but plenty of other black personalities Charles Barkley Ben Carson Stacey Dash Raven Symon etc The one thing all these guys have in common is an expressed favor of Eurocentric or mainstream American culture over black American culture But I call it passive cooning because the favor of white culture expressed by these individuals is well passive And it isn t followed up with an explicit disparagement of black people or black culture which is usually a tactic of aggressive cooning Unlike passive cooning aggressive cooning is an act where a black person consciously divorces themselves from black culture again in conjunction with the typical adoption of white American culture A prime example of what could be perceived as aggressive cooning would be Tree of Logic Let me preface this by making clear that this isn t me taking shots and calling Tree a coon To my knowledge we were cool until I randomly discovered she blocked me on Twitter but that s besides the point I m only using Tree as a strategic illustration you know it s not personal So first let me explain a little bit of background Tree of Logic is a YouTuber whose channel somewhat overlaps with mine in that we re both black right wing YouTubers which is basically a niche category because there s so few of us Anyway myself and Tree both at one point had some pretty vocal alliances with the alt right As of late I noticed we ve both slowly begun to separate ourselves from the movement Now I did so gradually in favor more so of promoting black capitalism and free association type stuff Tree however seemed to do so at the blink of an eye after she got BTFO d by Mike Enoch on the JQ She decided to chimp out and retreat back to normie conservatism Where I might add she s now hyperactively shilling for Israel and non racist white conservatives Which is you know whatever You do use this Now that s the background Here s how I believe she could be interpreted as a coon for this behavior Tree of Logic has openly said that she allied with the alt right only because she wanted to defend white people from the anti white left I have been a YouTuber for a year and a half now And during that time I have made anti Black Lives Matter videos and four self defense instructional videos encouraging and pleading with white people to protect themselves and defend themselves against anti white individuals I have always been forthcoming about my quest to help keep white people the majority here in America And I have viciously fought against anti white hatred Now this is quite different from my reasons which were voluntary separatism and decentralization of culture but that s fine You know she saw white people as a group being bullied and wanted to defend them Now she s doing so with the Jews you know Okay some could construe that as cooning but there s really not enough evidence to accuse her of it Unless you re one of those black people who think that you know any black person who s friendly towards white people is a coon Or I could even be charitable and say that Tree s rush to white night for white people and Jews is more so due to her conservatism than anything After all I ve also observed her to be dismissive of virtually any criticism towards police or Trump in what comes across as a dogmatic loyalty to Blue Lives Matter and a boomer tier MAGA fetish It s possible she could just be dogmatically defending white people and Jews because of her politics not her aversion to blacks However that s not all she believes Tree of Logic also happens to hold heavy contempt towards the black community not even necessarily certain elements within it but the group as a whole You see she doesn t seek to disassociate with the entire white community just because she doesn t like the alt right side of it but as shown in this tweet she s eager to disassociate from the black community as a whole presumably due to her disdain for groups like Black Lives Matter So if that s true then I could see why one would come to the conclusion that she s a coon because she is displaying favoritism to non black people whilst collectively condemning her own race for not being more culturally similar to the race she prefers Aggressive cooning is by far an extreme rarity not only because of the huge amounts of energy I suspect must go into impassioned countersignaling of the collective but more so its social consequences in terms of a personal relationship to the culture And this brings me to the final point I wanted to touch on and that s the consequential result of being accused of being a coon Most black Americans are natively settled in communities that have a distinctive blackness to them Now this can be defined in a number of ways such as the food the music the behavioral norms the language etc In essence blackness is just a synonym for common culture To be black genetically is not necessarily translative to being black culturally or being accepted as part of the cultural in group I want to make sure this is understood because it s something that seems to be lost on many non black people who object to the term coon There s a real world relevance behind the meme of who gets invited to the cookout Being of African descent doesn t necessarily mean you re entitled to a plate In fact a non black person who is unequivocally removed from black culture is far more likely to be welcomed by the community than a black person who s a cultural outcast but i think it is important to add that sometimes people who are black but don t you know really reflect black culture are incorrectly categorized as coons and this is for lack of better terms problematic probably the most well known synonym for coon is uncle tom now the term uncle tom originated from the book uncle tom s cabin where in the original writing he actually accepted being brutally beaten to death by his slave master because he refused to aggress against his fellow slaves or assist in their capture in order to do so however after the various film adaptations in the s the term uncle tom was repopularized to mean a slave who showed unconditional loyalty and servitude to the master stereotypically an uncle tom would serve as the master s right hand nigger you know receiving special privileges authority over other slaves and increased compassion from the master relative to the treatment of other slaves that is But another party who also received similar privileges and compassion were the house slaves Now a house slave could sometimes be an Uncle Tom but it wasn t an absolute Oftentimes house slaves were chosen not merely because of their obedience to the plantation s hierarchy but their fair skin their attractiveness and even secretive relations to the master It wasn t terribly uncommon for the unclaimed children conceived between the whites and the slaves to be granted refuge from field work because of their familiar relation Now I know some of you are wondering why I went on this totally random tangent but this is another important point that I failed to mention earlier in understanding what a coon by modern standards is not Oftentimes people will call other blacks who are simply raised outside of black culture a coon I actually recall back in middle school we had a student join who had just moved from London Let s call him D Anyway he was picked on pretty regularly regrettably i was guilty of this as well but he was teased and joned because he had a strong african british accent he was pretty feminine either gay or metrosexual and he didn t really act black you know as most of the students knew it now my school was black consistently from elementary through high school east metro atlanta and as a result the school was culturally homogenous So when Dee came many people accused him of being a coon because you could tell he had a distinct European fashion sense he had European vernacular and mannerisms etc But I think it s important to distinguish between a black person who favors white culture and projects that favoritism onto black communities such as Don Lemon from a black person who simply reflects the culture of which they were raised in like Dee A house slave who was merely raised around whites and has had white culture impressed upon them isn t the same as an Uncle Tom who consciously rejects and works to displace blackness By the way I m not saying that black people who are raised in white dominant cultures are house slaves It s just a metaphor The reason I wanted to bring this up is because I want people to know that being labeled a coon isn t always a mundane thing For people like me it s whatever because I don t really value external opinions nearly as much as most people besides most of the weirdos who call me coon are you know internet niggas talking shit over twitter most of the time white liberals guaranteed if any of them tried to accuse me of that shit within my atlanta social circles they d be laughed out of the room but for others it can have some pretty impactful social ramifications it s similar to being labeled a snitch in that regard you know it can dissolve social trust evict you from established relationships and in some extreme cases even put your safety at risk Kinda like the effect of being labeled a Nazi or a white supremacist While there are some legit Nazis out there often times the term is just a loaded smear campaign intended to silence or harm ideological opponents And a lot of people unfortunately use coon in the same way While in my opinion the term does have a legitimate role in being used it s much more common for it to just be weaponized by malicious people who don t like what you say or how you act Anyway guys that s going to do it for this video There is no real solution to the malicious use of the word coon but I think if more people understand what the term means and better understand how to use the language it could be mitigated And that s what I hope this video can serve as In the black community we have a unique language that for the most part is commonly understood I think I ve even seen it referred to as AV African American Vernacular English or Black English whatever you want to call it It s cultural communication and I think it s important for us to better solidify the meaning and intended usage of these terms Eventually the repeated real world usage of the term will establish a sort of pseudo consensus I just wanted to make this video anyway adding my own take explaining how I believe black people should define the term Thank you

Dr Carrie Madej She is a medical expert who has done research for decades and she has found some extremely disturbing things about the upcoming vaccine for COVID Dr Carrie Madej has been the medical director of two large clinics She has a vast medical experience and we are honored to have her here I want to encourage you to watch this video to the end so you can hear what she has to say This may well be the most important video you will ever watch in your life I am very excited to be here and I feel it s very urgent that we get this information out to everyone I started researching vaccines probably in my early s been very interested in them but never before have I seen the technology being used on this proposed COVID vaccine never before First of all this vaccine will be using a modified RNA or modified DNA in the vaccine So why is this important It s important to know because it could potentially alter our DNA our genome And what s the big deal about DNA or RNA Well our genome Well the genome is what makes us human what separates us from the rest of the animals and plants in the world It s the blueprint for what creates us how we reproduce how we function how we repair how we evolve So one little change one little protein inserted one taken out one changed can actually create a congenital defect or a hereditary disorder So a little change is grand So something that can alter that could really be devastating on us humans right So they re proposing to use this technology and part of this is called transfection okay transfection is the same technology being used to make a genetically modified organism such as a tomato or corn in the grocery store and we all know that Monsanto is pretty well known for making genetically modified organisms and they re not as healthy as the organic the the wild type that you see out in nature so if this is the same technology being used on the plants well what would happen to us humans Potentially we would not be as healthy okay And I want to remind everyone that this is the first time that it would be used on humans large scale We would be the experiment We would be the lab rats We don t have long term studies So this is very very important to know Let me just go and show you or tell you about one of the front runners for this vaccine That is Moderna Moderna has been given about billion from the U S government for research and development It s backed by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation So they have a lot of money backing them I wanted to let you know they re kind of the new kids on the block They really have not been around for that long They have never developed a human vaccine nor a human medicine ever This is their first run at it Also just to know for you to know that they have gone from fast track their vaccine light years OK so they went from a lab you know experiment to phase two which is using only human subjects in days Two months That s crazy We should have years behind that And I m going to remind you that this is the first time they ve ever developed a vaccine Their early studies so far showed that in their phase two which is using human subjects when they did introduce this vaccine into the human subjects percent of the high dose vaccine group percent got systemic side effects In the low dose vaccine group got systemic side effects So already we re seeing initially side effects Now long term we don t know So on Moderna one of the ways that they could apply this would be a proposal would be going to use a bandage called a microneedle platform So microneedle platform would be a bandage that you could get in the mail like Amazon or UPS It s a bandage you would apply on your hand here and then you take the sticker off and then voila you have a vaccine You do it yourself So how are they doing this The bandage has tiny little micro needles on it and it s designed after a snake fang or a viper fang So it s like a bite from a snake but many of them And they say you really won t feel it but it goes into your skin and the little tiny microneedles will be injected So what s in a microneedle It ll be either the DNA or the RNA vaccine Number two it ll be something called luciferase Now this is very important to know They patented an enzyme called luciferase okay So this is called luciferase they claim because it gives a bioluminescence a light okay And it s not something you can see or feel but if you have a special device like a smartphone app with a special application you can scan over it and it will light up It ll show a pattern a digital code a barcode a tattoo We re going to be branded Each person will have their own ID You know this reminds me of World War II You know it s something to think about being branded like a product in the store So that will be in there and that will hold proof that you re being vaccinated They want to make sure that you re scanned and that you ve gotten the vaccine So we ll be branded What could that be used for There s lots of technologies out there but it s something that we need to be concerned about So there s two things We have a brand new experimental DNA or RNA vaccine that could potentially alter our genome And number two we re going to be tattooed or branded with an ID And then number three this is all in a hydrogel So hydrogel is a technology that was invented by DARPA Department of Advanced Research Project Agency Now this is a small part of the Pentagon or the Department of Defense They make the sci fi inventions that you might hear about So this is one of their inventions You can look up on YouTube Hydrogel the company Profusa and DARPA and you ll see some clips of some of the technology of this So this is a special technology because it goes under the skin The body doesn t reject it and it has nanotechnology which are microscopic robotic organisms So these microscopic organisms that are robotic will be in your body okay They can assemble disassemble and reassemble and to do innumerable things into the body So the idea of this would be it s a way for it to gather information from your body So you could get your blood pressure your blood sugar your heart rate which sounds good Okay gather that information However it also has a potential to be used for other things It can gather how many steps you ve taken if you ve fallen if you re swimming if you re running if you re menstruating how your menstrual cycle goes if you re having sex if you re sleeping it actually has the potential to know your emotions Okay All of this data hours a day seven days a week days a year is being accumulated And where s it going Well they claim it goes to a smart app like your phone the iCloud or any smart device but who s getting this information Who is using it What are they using it for That has not been answered So the other important thing to know is they re gathering all this information about us and we re putting that out So we re being connected to artificial intelligence You have to know this is not just a vaccine We re being connected to artificial intelligence So just like a phone you have your smartphone You can send a text You can send an email But then the phone or someone else can send something back to you to your phone That means something can send something back to our bodies messages or information Well what could happen from that I could imagine that you could be affected with your mood or your behavior your memory That could really cause a lot of problems a lot of confusion And who s in charge of this The Department of Defense Bill and Melinda Gates Who s doing this We don t have answers yet But this is something real to know This is being proposed and I don t know if you ve heard of something Russia has spent the last few years growing its list of Western enemies But the country s relationship with Israel has only improved In spite of Russian support for Syria and a long history of tense adversarial relations Israel and Russia are close geopolitical allies So why exactly do the two countries love each other Well the political and social history of Russia and Israel is actually incredibly unique Early on in Israel s formation the Soviet Union was a major supporter of a Jewish state Allegedly Russian dictator Joseph Stalin expected the new country to be socialist and the USSR was even the second country in the world to recognize Israeli sovereignty after the United States However this support was not long lasting In an effort to gain control over the Middle East Russia funded and armed countries like Syria Iraq Libya Egypt and others Meanwhile the United States provided military and financial support to Israel creating a de facto adversary to the Soviet Union And yet in spite of their political divide the people of Israel and Russia have seen parallel social development Due to the Soviet Union s persecution of religion and in particular the country s state sanctioned anti Semitism Israel served as a welcoming home for Jewish Russians known as refuseniks In a group of refuseniks attempted to hijack an airplane in order to escape the Soviet Union And while they failed it drew international attention to the fact that conditions within Russia were terrible and those who wanted to leave weren t allowed to So throughout the s Russia allowed hundreds of thousands of Jewish Russians to leave the country and by an estimated had emigrated to Israel This mass migration of Jews was known as the Aliyah Once in Israel Russians were able to assimilate while introducing their own social norms including a focus on high culture such as theater literature music and art When the Soviet Union s last leader Mikhail Gorbachev opened the country s borders a second massive wave of Russian Jews came to Israel close to one million over the following decade and a half There are now more Russian Jews living in Israel than there are in Russia and Russia is the largest source of international Jews in Israel This enormous domestic influence of both Jewish culture in Russia and Russian culture in Israel may be the reason that both countries are incredibly sympathetic to each other in spite of their international disagreements In the early s the two populations elected leaders who were outspoken supporters of each other Russia s Vladimir Putin and Israel s Ariel Sharon Israel s current Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu himself has family roots in the former Russian Empire For the past decade much of Israel s ability to maintain both their sovereignty and avoiding international sanctions has stemmed from broad and equal support from both of the world s th century superpowers the United States and Russia In fact the US and Russia in addition to the United Nations and the European Union make up the Middle East Quartet which is a collection of national bodies working to solve the Israeli Palestinian crisis On the one hand Russia has been working to support the Syrian regime which has repeatedly attempted to destroy Israel Meanwhile Israel stands opposed to Iran Russia s longtime ally And yet the two countries have cultures and politics that are so deeply intertwined that their social bond is able to overcome any military divisiveness Iran and Israel have been opposed for decades To learn about why the two hate each other despite sharing allies watch this video right here Thanks for checking out NowThis World don t forget to like and subscribe for more videos like this every week

A year old African American girl says that her classmates called her hair ugly and nappy as they pinned her down and cut several of her dreadlocks CNN s Renee Marsh spoke to Amari Allen and her family about what happened year old sixth grader Amari Allen is healing after she says three white male classmates at Emanuel Christian School in Springfield Virginia targeted and attacked her because of her hair I was about to go down one of the sides when three boys came up to me like surrounded me and they put me on the ground one of them put my hand my hands on my back one put their hands over my mouth and one cut my hair the alleged attack on school grounds was both physical and verbal they were saying like my hair was ugly it was nappy they were saying that i don t deserve to live i shouldn t have been born the back of it was in the middle of her back and they cut all of these her grandmother says she was targeted for being different they attacked her as as whom god created her to be as a young lady of color Amari says it was the school bell that saved her when it rang We ran off laughing went back to the line and I just got myself up and went back to work It started the first day of school when they start taking her lunch and eating her lunch in front of her telling her these nasty words you re not fit to live Yeah you re not fit to live You re ugly Your hair is snappy You don t belong here The school told CNN in a statement we take seriously the emotional and physical well being of all of our students and have a zero tolerance policy for any kind of bullying or abuse The student body there is white and African American Emanuel Christian made news earlier this year because second lady Karen Pence teaches art part time there despite a school policy that bans gay students and parents Pence s office defended her decision to work there The Allen family filed a police report and the Fairfax County Police Department tells CNN they are now investigating You realize that you are beautiful right Yes And you realize that your hair is beautiful too right In the meantime Amari s family says they are reminding her daily that she is enough trying to reverse the negative impact of the painful words from her classmates We used to say sticks and stones will break my bones but words will never hurt Words will kill It s a lot of people today that have committed suicide over one word So words have deep scarring Well Amari missed a few days of school as a result of this incident but she plans to return And the school told CNN those involved in the incident will be out of school while police continue their investigation Now the family says that they do forgive these students but they want to see them receive some sort of punishment and counseling so that they never do this to anyone else again Renee Marsh CNN Washington

My concern is doing away with whiteness Whiteness is a form of racial oppression sure The suggestion is that it is somehow possible to separate whiteness from oppression and it is not There can be no white race without the phenomenon of white supremacy If you abolish slavery you abolish slaveholders In the same way if you abolish racial oppression you do away with whiteness Treason to whiteness is loyalty to humanity Your views are fairly well received in academia Yes they re legitimate not to say that everyone agrees but sure I could not point to any examples where it has provoked political censorship Whiteness is an identity that arises entirely out of oppression Whiteness is not a culture it s not a religion it s not a language it s simply an oppressive social category Blackness is an identity that can be plausibly argued Black Studies is the study of a people that has formed itself in resistance to its oppression The task is to bring this minority together in such a way that it makes it impossible for the legacy of whiteness to continue to reproduce itself At this point in time Europe has not yet learned how to be multicultural And I think we re going to be part of the throes of that transformation which must take place Europe is not going to be the monolithic societies that they once were in the last century Jews are going to be at the center of that It s a huge transformation for Europe to make They are now going into a multicultural mode and Jews will be resented because of our leading role But without that leading role and without that transformation Europe will not survive

decision maker for this company He died last night of non Hodgkin s lymphoma which he battled for some time It had taken him off multiple earnings calls though not out of the office throughout the last couple years His legacy Profound Every market he touched he changed Adelson s impact on Macau his vision for Singapore his dreams for Las Vegas He leaves his mark on every integrated resort in every destination He had a deep abiding love for Israel He donated generously to conservative politics there and smashed records for political donations in U S politics In fact according to the Center for Responsive Politics Sheldon Adelson and his wife were the single largest political donors of the election cycle giving million to Republican or conservative groups They had donated more than million in the midterms And in the presidential election they were Trump s biggest donors Sheldon Adelson had a massive impact on U S politics All of that of course was extraneous to the people who worked for him Many of his executive team had been with him for decades Head of communications Ron Reese told me today s a day when the housekeepers are crying over the death of Mr Adelson He was perceived as anti union but executives point out what he paid and he offered for benefits exceeded what unions secured for those workers And throughout the pandemic Las Vegas Sands has not laid off any of its employees globally which really I think stands out not just in the casino industry but in business in general Last Wednesday the company announced Adelson would take medical leave It was an indication of how seriously his health was declining The board named Rob Goldstein interim chairman and CEO signaling its thoughts about the potential future leadership here I also want to mention that the CFO Patrick Dumont is Sheldon s son in law and the family retains majority share Sheldon Adelson s funeral will be held I m told almost immediately in Israel with a memorial plan for a later date in Las Vegas Carl Contessa any clues as to whether or not or how the company s direction or focus might change You know after he announced medical leave last week we already saw analysts Famed music producer and convicted murderer Phil Spector has died at the age of The California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation revealed in a statement that Phil who had been an inmate at the California health care facility in Stockton California since had passed away from natural causes While it is currently unknown what caused Phil s death the CDCR noted that its official cause of death will be determined by the medical examiner in the San Joaquin County Sheriff s Office In the same statement the CDCR also included an updated mugshot of Phil that was taken last November Phil who often wore wigs before his conviction is seen bald and smiling in the recent mugshot Back in Phil was found guilty of second degree murder for the death of actress Lana Clarkson This conviction happened in a second trial after the first one was deadlocked in Phil ended up being sentenced to years to life in prison and was eligible for a parole hearing in Phil who was born Harvey Philip Spector in is known for revolutionizing rock and pop music in the s with his layered wall of sound production technique During his career Phil has produced music for legendary bands and artists such as The Beatles The Ramones and even Cher

Whether it s questions about curriculum or incidents of anti Semitism and hate the ADL has helped us if we ve missed the mark and mentored us and guided us We mark today with a ceremony of remembrance solidarity and hope Through the words of our tradition with the guidance and love of several of our diverse Jewish community spiritual leaders May we draw strength and inspiration from those who ve come before us as we invoke the guidance and presence of the divine Fear cannot be the driver of our life Instead we need to lead with chesed with love with generosity with compassion resilience and hope And I think it is critically important that the federal government recognize the role that it plays and make sure again that that support is cascading down through various ways through which we can call attention to it and fund programs to combat it So just because I talk about these issues of course it affected me and my family But I remember what my mom told me when I was nine years old She said stand up for something even if it means sacrificing everything And that s what I m trying to do The history between the NAACP and the ADL is critically important for us all to understand The NAACP and the ADL have walked in lockstep in the pursuit of freedom for all people the right of all of us to be self determinative and in the quest for the dignity of every human being And so today now more than ever I believe that it is critically important for us to continue that legacy We have to become the unwelcome guest at the dinner table And not just for the young people at the table but to telegraph the message that this is not acceptable But I think that if anything good can come from this moment it s for us to think about the fact that Jewish history is written in the present We are writing our chapter of Jewish history I thought that it was a very powerful experience and I ve been looking forward to this for a while I m probably going to go back to campus and continue to fight the fight against anti Semitism and not back down and stay strong Fighting anti Semitism must be it must be one of our priorities in the work to create justice inclusivity equity safety and security We are in this fight together Thank you for being here

Trump sends top officials to attend Christians Zionist conference Memo a number of senior officials in the Trump administration will be in attendance at a major gathering this week of powerful lobby group Christians United for Israel Hufi reported Haaretz According to the paper the conference will feature speeches by Vice President Mike Pence and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo as well as by Trump s National Security Advisor John Bolton his special envoy to the Middle East Jason Greenblatt and his ambassador to Israel David Friedman The annual summit held in Washington D C will take place today and tomorrow attracting thousands of evangelical Christians from across the U S Other speakers at the event include Republican Senators Ted Cruz of Texas Marco Rubio of Florida Roy Blunt of Missouri and Tim Scott of South Carolina Although CUFI describes itself as bipartisan organization no Democratic senators are scheduled to speak According to Haaretz the decision to send senior administration officials to the CUFI gathering is no coincidence since evangelicals are a key voting bloc for Trump and the Republicans Around of white evangelicals voted for Trump in helping him secure victories in several swing states the paper stated The consensus among U S political analysts is that the president will need similar or greater support among evangelicals to win a second term next year When the Trump administration relocated the U S embassy to Jerusalem CUFI founder Texas pastor John Hagee gave a speech at the opening ceremony declaring There has never been a more pro Israeli president than Donald Trump The paper added that for Trump the support of the overwhelming majority of white evangelicals those who voted for him in and who love his Israel policies is crucial According to recent reports the president s re election campaign will seek to mobilize even more evangelical voters This article originally appeared on Middle East Monitor

In a five year period workers died Thai workers in the Israeli agricultural sector I was at a Moshav the day after a worker died in his sleep He d been working hours a day seven days a week and he d been given four days off per year In all of the cases that we encounter until now that a Thai worker had died in his sleep nobody went to actually check how many hours he worked in that day what kind of accommodation they had if he was spraying or not spraying pesticides What concerns us greatly is whether or not these living and working conditions are contributing to the very problematic pattern of death There are approximately Thai workers in Israel right now almost exclusively doing all the work in Israel s agricultural sector Since when Israel signed a bilateral agreement with the government of Thailand Thailand it s only been Thai workers who ve been coming in We need them for our economy The farmer will shut their field and shut their business if they don t have workers And only foreign workers come to work in agriculture So we have to treat them as our guests and to take care of them When we visit these workers you keep finding the same problems workers living really squalid accommodation Before he was a store they put in chemical and motor and everything broken he keep inside The farmer would usually just let the workers live in the cheapest place he can find His old packaging house his old warehouse his old chicken houses It s usually in the backyard of every big villa in every village If we go to the toilet we go to the outside under the tree So there was no toilet No toilet year old year old men and women that are here to work for five years and three months it s supposed to be their home And none of the farmers and me or any Knesset member will allow their kids to sleep in these places We conducted a survey among workers no one was getting minimum wage They said that the monthly wage was around Yes But it didn t reach or a month We work every day for days Workers have to spray pesticides Many of the workers we spoke to were clearly not given adequate protection when they did that I haven t been given a hand in a year I have to buy it all the time I think there s a chemical problem in ASEAN and I m going to go crazy I think I have to quit that day In the summer when it s outside it can get up to degrees and then in there it gets up to degrees It s very very hard to breathe in this situation Workers are working incredibly long hours in incredible heat And in some cases there s this great concern that workers may in fact be being worked to death The employer is fully aware that the likelihood of any prosecution for him violating workers rights is very low So if he wants to make a worker work for hours a day he can When you have excellent laws in place you have the perception that this is a very well regulated sector But if those laws aren t properly enforced then you move quickly to what is in fact a very badly regulated sector There should be an office or a department that says we are responsible we re the only one that s responsible for the foreign workers They come here for five years they leave their Ron and Janelle we talked about the major issues facing this country the pandemic the racial unrest The vice president recently met with black faith leaders in Maryland I asked him about how the administration is handling social justice reform First off we re not going to defund the police The reality is that more than of the men and women that put on the uniform of law enforcement every day are the very best of us Barbara And whether it s in Lancaster or across Pennsylvania or across America the American people know that Now that doesn t mean that we don t have an opportunity to advance some common sense reforms The president and I have been meeting with African American community leaders We ll be continuing to do that We ll be listening very intently Look the death of George Floyd was a national tragedy It shocked the conscience of the nation And we re speaking to law enforcement officials about how we can give further guidance on the appropriate use of force how we can provide additional resources for training law enforcement officers The vice president says the administration does not plan to stop there but plans to address long term historic inequities that he blames on failed liberal policies He also says unemployment was the lowest ever recorded for African Americans under President Trump Barbara Barr WGAL News

the system While Boasian anthropology was spread by a careful process of the development of cadres and placing them in key positions over the course of a generation the Frankfurt School very quickly In early th century Florence almost all financial cases that came before the magistrates in the police court involved Jews Not many not most but almost all I couldn t believe it either but I spent years going through the Florentine police records And this wasn t the sad old story of police persecution The suits were usually initiated by the Jews themselves Debt collection was an intensely adversarial process and the usual method was to force a settlement by having the Christian defaulter arrested and jailed and on rare occasions Jews had Jewish debtors imprisoned as well not nice Not kosher either as a matter of fact

Children had only just started to head back to school in France but after only one week of classes around are having to shut down once more as cases of Covid have been detected It is probably a virus that was contracted before returning to school after exiting confinement We ll see what the analyses say This is what many teachers and their unions had warned about They implored the government not to reopen schools fearing that they could become hotspots for the transmission of the virus Parents had also been raising their own concerns They ve been asking us if we want to send the kids back and you know they have mixed feelings Everything just opened up So we re actually sort of continuing as we were for a few weeks to see what happens in the next three weeks I personally think we re going to end up back in lockdown I don t feel like everything s opened up though because the danger is gone I think everything has opened up because financially they can t afford to keep it closed and because people are losing their minds But I think it was also opened up because now if a whole lot of people get ill there are beds and ventilators to latest Though many measures were put in place to stop the virus spreading it appears that they just weren t enough The government insists the schools that are closing down again are only a small percentage overall And it says the consequences of children not going to school are more serious However while the number of children who ve contracted COVID is relatively small there is another alarming trend that s been emerging Last week France registered the first case of a child dying from a rare complication linked to coronavirus The child presented symptoms resembling Kawasaki disease The serological test done within the pediatric ICU unit indicated that he had been in contact with the coronavirus without developing the symptoms the prior week It s a rare inflammatory disease that normally affects children under the age of five But since the Covid pandemic children across the world have been showing similar symptoms In France there have been more than reported cases since the beginning of March At present parents in France can decide whether or not to send their children back to school But given these new cases of COVID centred around reopened schools and the surge in more complex cases involving children many parents just may decide that it is still too risky Charlotte Dubinsky RT Paris Thank you
